answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I found some documents that you might find useful.
This article from the University of Georgia called, Tenure of City Managers: Examining the Dual Meanings of “Average Tenure”, looks to answer a question very similar to the one you ask.
http://www.jstor.org/pss/4355387
I also looked into some examples of contract lengths. 
The following places have use a contract of three years.
Sealy City, TX
http://www.sealynews.com/news/article_1d2e7afa-a841-11e0-878e-001cc4c03286.html\
Eastpointe, MI
http://www.cityofeastpointe.net/managercontract.pdf
Laguna Beach, CA
http://www.lagunabeachcity.net/civica/filebank/blobdload.asp?BlobID=7453
I also found a 5 year example from Worcester, MA.
http://nuweb9.neu.edu/watchdognewengland/Worcester_city_contract.pdf
And the longest contract was from Marietta, GA.
http://mdjonline.com/view/full_story/14485214/article-Contract-for-city-manager-is-extended?instance=home_news_bullets
Ali Iannolo
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

Pennsylvania statutes only allow for two year contracts for Managers. Most serve longer, I have been in my current position for eleven year.

author: Charles Smith
text: Our current city manager has been employed by our village for five years.  Currrently our village board is considering renewing his contract.  We are looking at a new five year renewal contract with two two year options. Does this type of agreement seem normal or are there certain guidelines we need to consider before renewing this contract.  Also what is the average length of time that a city managers servers before moving on to another community.
title: Length of City Manager Contracts
